label: PTB-XL
version_info: Version 1.0.1 includes ECG signals in raw and filtered formats, structured metadata annotations (diagnostic, form, rhythm), and patient-level metadata.
title: Large Publicly Available Electrocardiography Dataset (PTB-XL)
description: PTB-XL is a large publicly available electrocardiography (ECG) dataset containing clinical 12-lead ECG signals from 21,837 records of 18,885 patients. It is designed for machine learning and deep learning research, and includes both raw signals and extensive annotations in a structured form.
purpose: To provide a large-scale benchmark dataset for ECG analysis and machine learning-based classification, diagnosis, prognosis prediction, as well as generative tasks such as synthesis and data augmentation.
study_design: Retrospective observational study conducted using ECG data from routine clinical care at a tertiary care hospital.
patient_criteria: Inclusion: ECG recordings from patients referred to a tertiary care university hospital for suspected cardiovascular conditions. Exclusion: ECG recordings with corrupted or missing leads were excluded.
target_variables: Diagnostic labels including myocardial infarction, bundle branch block, ST/T changes, hypertrophy, arrhythmia, and other ECG abnormalities.
time_zero: The baseline was the date when a 10-second 12-lead ECG recording was taken for each patient.
acquisition_methods: The PTB-XL dataset includes 12-lead clinical ECG recordings acquired using standardised medical equipment in a clinical setting. The data were collected using Schiller AG ECG devices during routine care. Each recording is 10 seconds long and has been annotated by cardiologists. Two versions are available: raw signals at 500 Hz and downsampled versions at 100 Hz.
privacy_compliance: Data were fully anonymised prior to publication according to PhysioNet standards. No identifying personal data are included.

ethics_approval.details: Study approved for public sharing of anonymised ECG data for research purposes.

patient_consent.details: Patient consent was obtained for data use in anonymised form for research purposes.
